to lessening racial discriminations in the Johns Hopkins University and surrounding community has recently been formed.

Farrell, a graduate student in
American history, tht organization is working closely with Dr.
Chester Wickwire.
After a meeting with leaders
of the local NAACP, Urban
League, and Equal Employment
Opportunity Commissions, the
Hopkins group decided that it
could be more effective calling
attention to and trying to eliminate discriminatory practices
within the University than by
conducting §it-ins and demonstrations outside the University.
Before taking any definite reform action, the anti-discrimination group plans to gather factual
information on the extent and
nature of racial inequalities in
the University and in the immediate surrounding community.

The Johns Hopkins University
closed its fiscal year last June 30
without a deficit in any of its
schools or divisions, according to
the Annual Report of Henry S.
Baker, Treasurer'and Vice President for Finance. The University,
on an overall basis, has operated
slightly in the black for the last
four years, but this is the first
time since 1945 that every school
has avoided a deficit, university
officials noted.

in current general funds of $180,856, compared with $119,171 for
the previous year. Current expenditures for operations for the
year were $53,589,740.

S. Eizenh-wer said:
"The results shown in Mr.
Baker's report are satisfying on
..-..?.v3ral counts. The fact that the

schools is attributable in no small
measure to prudent management
of available funds by faculty
leaders and the officers of the
several divisions.

fact that Hopkins has operated
in the black without sacrificing
steady progress. For the sixth
successive year, it was possible

to carry out a selective but significant program of very much
needed faculty salary increases.

some new departments necessary

The Gentlemen's Code is a self-imposed moral code of a community of gentlemen. This is the very essence of the Hopkins Tradition. Over the years, there have been many attempts at cramping
that revered tradition, and yet all have failed simply because those
in the community have not wanted to lower the level of their
Self-imposed code. It was only last year that the dorms officially
added a third ruling, concerning firearms (the other two were
about fire and firecrackers, and women in the rooms.)
The opening of this school year again finds someone gnawing
at the Tradition, this time by trying to interpret the Gentleman's
Code in quite a different way. Mr. Barter, head dormitory advisor
has informed all the house presidents that they will now be responsible for all the actions of those in their entry—especially
the freshmen. In addition, they have been instructed to teach the
lrosh 'the correct etiquette' commensurate with the correct way of
living, and they are also on their honor to report to Mr. Barter
any student who breaches this interpretation of the Code. This
isn't Hopkins! This is a training school for erring boys, and a lesson
in nurse-maid for the dorm leaders.
Hopkins has always given its students, as the old adage goes,
'enough rope to hang themselves' and yet for some 'unexplained'
reason she happens to be producing finer and better-prepared
citizens every year. Subscribing to the philosophy that good judgment comes from experience, and experience comes from bad
judgment, we find ourselves wondering why today's incoming classes
are not being given the same opportunity to develop into responsible men as was afforded those in past classes according to the
inbred traditions of the Gentlemen's Code.

ceiling for a self-starter in this business."

it—you'll want to visit your Placement Office for

sorority girl.
First, let us take up the matter of housemothers. The
housemother is your friend, your guide, your mentor. You
must treat her with respect. When you wish to speak to her,
address her as "Mother Sigafoos" or "Ma'am." In no circumstances must you say, "Hey, fat lady."
Second, let us discuss laundry. Never hang your wash o,n
the front porch of the sorority house. This is unsightly and
shows a want of breeding. Use the Chapter Room.
Third, meals. Always remember that planning and preparing
meals for a houseful of healthy girls is no simple task. Your
cook goes to a great deal of trouble to make your menu varied
and nourishing. The least you can do is show your appreciation. Don't just devour your food; praise it. Exclaim with
delight,"What delicious pork jowls!" or "What a yummy soup
bone!" or "What scrumptious fish heads!" or "What clear
water!"
Fourth, clothing. Never forget that your appearance reflects not just on yourself but on the whole house. It was
well enough before you joined a sorority to lounge around
tampus in your old middy blouse and gym bloomers, but now
you must take great pains to dress in a manner which excites
admiring comments from all who'observe you. A few years ago,
for example, there was a Chi Omega named Camille Ataturk
at the University of Iowa who brought gobs of glory to all her
sorors. Camille hit on the ingenious notion of suiting her garb

wore a buskin and jerkin. To German she wore lederhosen and
carried a stein of pilsener. To Econ she wore 120 yards of
ticker tape. Her shiningest hour cattle one day when she
dressed as a white mouse for Psych Lab. Not only her Chi
Omega sisters, but the entire student body went into deep
mourning when she was killed by the janitor's cat.

Finally, let us take up the most important topic of all. I
refer, of course, to dating.
As we have seen, the way you dress reflects on your sorority,
but the men you dafe reflect even more. Be absolutely certain
that your date is an acceptable fellow. Don't beat about the
bush; ask him point-blank, "Are you an acceptable fellow?"
Unless he replies, "Yeah, hey," send him packing.
But don't just take his word that he is acceptable. Inspect
him closely. Are his fingernails clean? Is his black leather
jacket freshly oiled? Is his ukelele in tune? Does he (wry
